japanese.content: リンゴを食べたりバナナを食べたりしました
リンゴをたべたりバナナをたべたりしました
ringo wo tabetari banana wo tabetari simasu

translated.content: I ate apples and ate bananas.

title.content: Listing subjects and objects(主語や目的語の並列)

japanese.content: バスやタクシーは便利だ
バスやタクシーはべんりだ
basu ya takusi wa benri da
コーラやオレンジジュースを飲んだ
コーラやオレンジジュースをのんだ

translated.content: I drank cola and orange juice.

japanese.content: テレビを見たり先生に聞いたりしました
テレビをみたり先生にきいたりしました
terebi wo mitari sensei ni kiitari simasita

translated.content: I watched TV, asked the teacher a question, and did other things.

japanese.content: お菓子を食べたり宿題をしたりする
おかしをたべたりしゅくだいをしたりする
okasi wo tabetari shukudai wo sitari suru

translated.content: I eat sweets, do my homework, and do other things.

japanese.content: 勝負で勝ったり負けたりする
しょうぶでかったりまけたりする

translated.content: Sometimes I win games and sometimes I lose.

u.b: Grammar Point 1: Listing subjects and objects with "ya"

grammar_points.p: You have already studied the list marker "to", which translates as the English word "and" and is used to give a complete list of nouns as the subject or direct object of a sentence. The incomplete list marker "ya" is similar, but it implies some other nouns are not mentioned in the sentence.
コーラとお茶を飲みました - "I drank cola and tea."
コーラやお茶を飲みました - "I drank cola, tea, and other things."

In the first sentence in the example above, the speaker is only talking about cola and tea. But in the second sentence, the implication is that the speaker drank many things but is only mentioning two of them.

u.b: Grammar Point 2: The "tari" form of verbs

grammar_points.p: When enumerating an incomplete list of actions, a form of the verb called the "tari" form is used. Each action mentioned is put into the "tar" form, and the verb "suru" is added to the end of the sentence. The "tari" form of verbs is constructed by adding a "ri" sound to the end of the plain past tense. The tense of the sentence is determined by the "suru" at the end.

When the "tari" form of verbs is used to enumerate a few actions out of a larger list, it performs the same function that "ya" does for nouns. In other words, it indicates that there were additional actions which were not mentioned in the sentence. No relative order of the actions is implied.
週末はテレビを見たり本を読んだりします - "On weekends I watch TV, read books, and so on."
学校で友達と話したり勉強したりします - "At school I talk to my friends, study, and do other things."

The "tari" form is also used to describe alternating states or repeating actions done by the same subject. This usage carries the nuance that sometimes the subject is or does one thing, and at other times it is or does something else.
勝負で勝ったり負けたりする - "Sometimes I win games and sometimes I lose."
バスは来たり来なかったりします - "Sometimes the bus comes and sometimes it doesn't."
